Exercise 29.4

Let fff and ggg be differentiable functions on an open interval III. Suppose a,ba, ba,b in III satisfy a<ba < ba<b and f(a)=f(b)=0f\p{a} = f\p{b} = 0f(a)=f(b)=0. Show f′(X)=f(x)g′(x)=0f'\p{X} = f\p{x}g'\p{x} = 0f′(X)=f(x)g′(x)=0 for some x∈(a,b)x \in \p{a, b}x∈(a,b). Hint: Consider h(X)=f(X)eg(x)h\p{X} = f\p{X} e^{g\p{x}}h(X)=f(X)eg(x).

Solution.

Since fff, ggg, and exe^xex are differentiable on III, the product rule and chain rule imply that hhh is also differentiable on III with

h′(x)=f′(x)eg(x)+f(x)g′(x)eg(x).h'\p{x} = f'\p{x}e^{g\p{x}} + f\p{x}g'\p{x} e^{g\p{x}}.h′(x)=f′(x)eg(x)+f(x)g′(x)eg(x).

Moreover, since f(a)=f(b)=0f\p{a} = f\p{b} = 0f(a)=f(b)=0, we immediately see that h(a)=h(b)=0h\p{a} = h\p{b} = 0h(a)=h(b)=0 as well. Thus, by Rolle's theorem, there exists x∈(a,b)x \in \p{a, b}x∈(a,b) such that

f′(x)eg(x)+f(x)g′(x)eg(x)=0  ⟹  f′(x)+f(x)g′(x), f'\p{x}e^{g\p{x}} + f\p{x}g'\p{x} e^{g\p{x}} = 0 \implies f'\p{x} + f\p{x}g'\p{x},f′(x)eg(x)+f(x)g′(x)eg(x)=0⟹f′(x)+f(x)g′(x),

where in the last step, we used that et≠0e^t \neq 0et=0 for all t∈Rt \in \Rt∈R to divide through by eg(x)e^{g\p{x}}eg(x).

Exercise 32.6

Let fff be a bounded function on [a,b]\br{a, b}[a,b]. Suppose there exist sequences (Un)\p{U_n}(Un​) and (Ln)\p{L_n}(Ln​) upper and lower Darboux sums for fff such that lim⁡n→∞(Un−Ln)=0\lim_{n\to\infty} \p{U_n - L_n} = 0limn→∞​(Un​−Ln​)=0. Show fff is integrable and ∫abf=lim⁡n→∞Un=lim⁡n→∞Ln\int_a^b f = \lim_{n\to\infty} U_n = \lim_{n\to\infty} L_n∫ab​f=limn→∞​Un​=limn→∞​Ln​.

Solution.

Since fff is bounded, U(f)U\p{f}U(f) and L(f)L\p{f}L(f) are well-defined. Moreover, Theorem 32.4 and the definitions of U(f)U\p{f}U(f) and L(f)L\p{f}L(f) imply

0≤U(f)−L(f)≤Un−Ln→n→∞0.0 \leq U\p{f} - L\p{f} \leq U_n - L_n \xrightarrow{n\to\infty} 0.0≤U(f)−L(f)≤Un​−Ln​n→∞​0.

Thus, U(f)=L(f)U\p{f} = L\p{f}U(f)=L(f), so fff is integrable. Next,

Ln≤L(f)=∫abf=U(f)≤Un  ⟹  0≤∫abf−Ln≤Un−Ln.L_n \leq L\p{f} = \int_a^b f = U\p{f} \leq U_n \implies 0 \leq \int_a^b f - L_n \leq U_n - L_n.Ln​≤L(f)=∫ab​f=U(f)≤Un​⟹0≤∫ab​f−Ln​≤Un​−Ln​.

By the squeeze theorem, lim⁡n→∞(∫abf−Ln)=0\lim_{n\to\infty} \p{\int_a^b f - L_n} = 0limn→∞​(∫ab​f−Ln​)=0, which also implies that lim⁡n→∞Ln=∫abf\lim_{n\to\infty} L_n = \int_a^b flimn→∞​Ln​=∫ab​f (since ∫abf\int_a^b f∫ab​f is a constant!). Finally,

Un=(Un−Ln)+Ln→n→∞∫abfU_n = \p{U_n - L_n} + L_n \xrightarrow{n\to\infty} \int_a^b fUn​=(Un​−Ln​)+Ln​n→∞​∫ab​f

as well (by limit laws).

Common Mistakes

The most common big mistake I saw was something like this:

Since lim⁡n→∞(Un−Ln)=0\lim_{n\to\infty} \p{U_n - L_n} = 0limn→∞​(Un​−Ln​)=0, we have lim⁡n→∞Un=lim⁡n→∞Ln\lim_{n\to\infty} U_n = \lim_{n\to\infty} L_nlimn→∞​Un​=limn→∞​Ln​. Thus, ...

Remember that limits are additive when both limits exist--take another look at the assumptions of Theorem 9.3.

In the same vein, many students who made this mistake also made the following one:

We must have lim⁡n→∞Un=U(f)\lim_{n\to\infty} U_n = U\p{f}limn→∞​Un​=U(f) and lim⁡n→∞Ln=L(f)\lim_{n\to\infty} L_n = L\p{f}limn→∞​Ln​=L(f), so ...

Even if you did know that (Un)\p{U_n}(Un​) and (Ln)\p{L_n}(Ln​) both converge to the same number, more work needs to be done to show that lim⁡n→∞Un=U(f)\lim_{n\to\infty} U_n = U\p{f}limn→∞​Un​=U(f) and lim⁡n→∞Ln=L(f)\lim_{n\to\infty} L_n = L\p{f}limn→∞​Ln​=L(f). To prove this, you would need to use Theorem 32.4 and the definitions of U(f)U\p{f}U(f) and L(f)L\p{f}L(f) (that they're the supremum and infimum of some set, respectively).

Lastly, the most common small mistake was this:

Since lim⁡n→∞(Un−Ln)=0\lim_{n\to\infty} \p{U_n - L_n} = 0limn→∞​(Un​−Ln​)=0, given any ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0 we have a partition PnP_nPn​ such that

U(f,Pn)−L(f,Pn)=Un−Ln<εU\p{f, P_n} - L\p{f, P_n} = U_n - L_n < \varepsilonU(f,Pn​)−L(f,Pn​)=Un​−Ln​<ε

for sufficiently large nnn. Thus, fff is integrable by Theorem 32.5.

The issue here is that you're not given that UnU_nUn​ and LnL_nLn​ correspond to the same partition, so you can't invoke Theorem 32.5 immediately. However, there is an easy fix: you do know that Un=U(f,Pn)U_n = U\p{f, P_n}Un​=U(f,Pn​) and Ln=L(f,Qn)L_n = L\p{f, Q_n}Ln​=L(f,Qn​) for some partitions Pn,QnP_n, Q_nPn​,Qn​, so by Lemma 32.2 applied to the common refinement Pn,Qn⊆Pn∪QnP_n, Q_n \subseteq P_n \cup Q_nPn​,Qn​⊆Pn​∪Qn​,

U(f,Pn∪Qn)−L(f,Pn∪Qn)≤U(f,Pn)−L(f,Qn).U\p{f, P_n \cup Q_n} - L\p{f, P_n \cup Q_n} \leq U\p{f, P_n} - L\p{f, Q_n}.U(f,Pn​∪Qn​)−L(f,Pn​∪Qn​)≤U(f,Pn​)−L(f,Qn​).
